Description¶

Math operations for common calculations required in Maya.

Vectors¶

Describe a magnitude and direction within some coordinate space. They have no inherent position.

Points¶

Describe a position within some coordinate space. The position is relative to a fixed origin. They can be described relative to each other using vectors.

A simple analogy is time. Values such as 3:00 and 5:00 can be considered coordinates. Durations such as +2 hours can be considered vectors between time coordinates.

Cartesian Coordinates¶

Represent coordinates in n-dimensional Euclidean space using n numbers. For example a 3-dimensional point is defined using [x,y,z] coordinates. It is impossible to express a point at infinity whilst maintaining directionality.

Homogenous Coordinates¶

Graphics softwares such as Maya require a uniform way to represent points at infinity (ie. direction vectors) as well as finite Euclidean points. It is possible to do so using a projective space which is an extension of Euclidean space. Points in projective space can be represented using homogeneous coordinates. These coordinates allow multiple transforms such as translation, rotation, scaling and projection to be efficiently encoded within a single matrix.

  • They represent n-dimensional coordinates with n+1 numbers.
  • For example a 3-dimensional point is defined using [x,y,z,w] coordinates.
  • This coordinate can be converted to a Cartesian form using [x/w, y/w, z/w].
  • A point at infinity (ie. direction vector) is expressed using w=0.
  • They are scale invariant meaning the following points are equal: [x,y,z,w], [A*x,A*y,A*z,A*w].

Matrices¶

Matrices can be used to encode multiple transformations within a single entity. Maya uses 4x4 matrices to represent transformations within 3-dimensional space.

  • Translations are encoded within the fourth row using w=1.
  • Rotations are encoded within the first three rows using an orthonormal basis of direction vectors, each with w=0.
  • Scaling is encoded down the diagonal from top-left to bottom-right.

Maya¶

The Maya API makes a distinction between vectors and points via its OpenMaya.MVector and OpenMaya.MPoint classes.

  • An OpenMaya.MVector is a displacement in 3-dimensional Euclidean space.
  • An OpenMaya.MPoint is a point in the 3-dimensional projective space represented by homogeneous coordinates.
  • Subtracting one OpenMaya.MPoint from another will return an OpenMaya.MVector representing the displacement between points.
  • Multiplying an OpenMaya.MPoint [x,y,z,0] by a matrix will return a new OpenMaya.MPoint relative to the rotation and scale encoded by the matrix. The result is a transformed direction vector. The [x,y,z] coordinates may require normalization if scaling was present.
  • Multiplying an OpenMaya.MPoint [x,y,z,1] by a matrix will return a new OpenMaya.MPoint relative to the translation, rotation and scale encoded by the matrix.

Note

  1. The homogeneous coordinate [0,0,0,0] is undefined in projective space. There is no line to project.

Note

  1. Maya does not enforce strict conventions between vectors and points. For example an OpenMaya.MVector will be treated as a Cartesian coordinate when used to instantiate an OpenMaya.MPoint.

Note

  1. As an optimisation, the following interface does not account for shear transforms encoded within transformation matrices. Alternative implementations which handle shearing can be found in the source code of this module.

Note

  1. Certain information is lost within the encoding of a transformation matrix. The following assumptions are applied by this interface and the OpenMaya API when attempting to extract rotation and scaling data from a transformation matrix.
    • Negative scaling in any single axis will be extracted as negative scaling in the z-axis.
    • Negative scaling in any two axes will be extracted as a rotation around the third axis.

Warning

  1. OpenMaya.MPoint.cartesianize() fails for infinite points on the projected cartesian planes. For example the point [0,1,0,0] represents a point at infinity in the y-basis direction. Maya will ‘cartesianize’ this point as [nan,inf,nan,1] instead of the expected result [inf,inf,inf,1]. Operations such as OpenMaya.MPoint.distanceTo() which rely on OpenMaya.MPoint.cartesianize() will also fail. The following interface does not handle this edge case.

Warning

  1. Certain OpenMaya classes define special instances via the class attributes listed below. These attributes provide a reference to a single instantiation. This behaviour is dangerous since the instance is mutable. Changes made to these instances will affect all current and future references to the attribute and should therefore be avoided.
    • OpenMaya.MVector.kOneVector, OpenMaya.MVector.kXaxisVector, OpenMaya.MVector.kXnegAxisVector, OpenMaya.MVector.kYaxisVector, OpenMaya.MVector.kYnegAxisVector, OpenMaya.MVector.kZaxisVector, OpenMaya.MVector.kZnegAxisVector, OpenMaya.MVector.kZeroVector.
    • OpenMaya.MPoint.kOrigin.
    • OpenMaya.MMatrix.kIdentity.
    • OpenMaya.MQuaternion.kIdentity.
exception msTools.core.maya.math_utils.InvalidPointError¶

Bases: exceptions.Exception

Exception to raise when:

  • Attempting to operate on or return the indeterminate homogeneous coordinate [0,0,0,0].
  • Attempting to operate on or return a homogeneous coordinate composed of float('nan') values.
exception msTools.core.maya.math_utils.InvalidVectorError¶

Bases: exceptions.Exception

Exception to raise when:

  • Attempting to operate on or return a vector composed of float('nan') values.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.angleBetween(vector1, vector2)¶

Return the unsigned angle between two vectors.

Parameters:
  • vector1 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
  • vector2 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
Returns:

float – The angle between point1 and point2 in radians.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.areClose(a, b, rTolerance=2.220446049250313e-16, aTolerance=0.0)¶

Check if two values are approximately equal as determined by the given absolute and relative tolerances.

Parameters:
  • a (numeric) – First value.
  • b (numeric) – Second value.
  • rTolerance (numeric, optional) – Relative tolerance, scaled to account for very large inputs. The scaling factor is given by max(max(a, b), 1). Defaults to the machine epsilon on sys.float_info.
  • aTolerance (numeric, optional) – Absolute tolerance. Defaults to 0.0.
Raises:

ValueError – If rTolerance or aTolerance are negative.
Returns:

bool – True if abs(a - b) is less than the maximum tolerance, otherwise False. The maximum tolerance is either the aTolerance or the scaled rTolerance.

Example

# Checks if `abs(a - b)` is less than an absolute tolerance
# Returns `False` because `abs(a - b) > aTolerance`
areClose(10.0, 10.1, rTolerance=0.0, aTolerance=0.01)

# Checks if `abs(a - b)` is less than a relative tolerance.
# Returns `True` because `abs(a - b) < (rTolerance * max(a, b))`
areClose(10.0, 10.1, rTolerance=0.01, aTolerance=0.0)
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.areCloseCoordinates(a, b)¶

Check if two coordinates are approximately equal as determined by the default Maya tolerance OpenMaya.MVector.kTolerance.

The Maya tolerance is scaled to account for very large inputs. The scaling factor is given by max(max(a, b), 1).

Parameters:
  • a (numeric) – First coordinate.
  • b (numeric) – Second coordinate.
Returns:

bool – True if abs(a - b) is less than the scaled Maya tolerance, otherwise False.

Example

# Checks if `abs(a - b)` is less than the scaled Maya tolerance.
# Returns `True` because `abs(a - b) < OpenMaya.MVector.kTolerance * max(a, b)`
areCloseCoordinates(10.0, 10.0000000001)
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.areClosePoints(a, b)¶

Check if two points are approximately equal as determined by the default Maya tolerance OpenMaya.MVector.kTolerance.

The Maya tolerance is scaled to account for very large inputs. The scaling factor is given by max(max(a[i], b[i]), 1) for each coordinate i.

Parameters:
  • a (iterable [numeric]) – First position in 3-dimensional projective space represented by homogeneous coordinates [x,y,z,w].
  • b (iterable [numeric]) – Second position in 3-dimensional projective space represented by homogeneous coordinates [x,y,z,w].
Returns:

bool – True if abs(a[i] - b[i]) is less than the scaled Maya tolerance for each coordinate i, otherwise False.

Example

# Checks if `abs(a[i] - b[i])` is less than the scaled Maya tolerance for each coordinate `i`
# Returns `True` because `abs(a[i] - b[i]) < OpenMaya.MVector.kTolerance * max(a[i], b[i])` for each coordinate `i`
areClosePoints([10.0, 10000.0, 10000000.0, 1.0], [10.0000000001, 10000.0000001, 10000000.0001, 1.0])
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.areCloseVectors(a, b)¶

Check if two vectors are approximately equal as determined by the default Maya tolerance OpenMaya.MVector.kTolerance.

The Maya tolerance is scaled to account for very large inputs. The scaling factor is given by max(max(a[i], b[i]), 1) for each coordinate i.

Parameters:
  • a (iterable [numeric]) – First vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
  • b (iterable [numeric]) – Second vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
Returns:

bool – True if abs(a[i] - b[i]) is less than the scaled Maya tolerance for each coordinate i, otherwise False.

Example

# Checks if `abs(a[i] - b[i])` is less than the scaled Maya tolerance for each coordinate `i`
# Returns `True` because `abs(a[i] - b[i]) < OpenMaya.MVector.kTolerance * max(a[i], b[i])` for each coordinate `i`
areCloseVectors([10.0, 10000.0, 10000000.0], [10.0000000001, 10000.0000001, 10000000.0001])
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.averagePoint(point1, point2, weight=0.5)¶

Return the weighted average of two positions.

Parameters:
  • point1 (iterable [numeric]) – Position in 3-dimensional projective space represented by homogeneous coordinates [x,y,z,w].
  • point2 (iterable [numeric]) – Position in 3-dimensional projective space represented by homogeneous coordinates [x,y,z,w].
  • weight (float, optional) – Weight the result towards point1 or point2. Valid values are in the interval [0.0, 1.0]. Small values bias point1. Large values bias point2. Defaults to 0.5 - no bias.
Raises:

ValueError – If weight is less than 0.0 or greater than 1.0.
Returns:

OpenMaya.MPoint – The weighted average of point1 and point2.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.averageVector(vector1, vector2, weight=0.5)¶

Return the weighted average of two vectors.

Parameters:
  • vector1 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
  • vector2 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
  • weight (float, optional) – Weight the result towards vector1 or vector2. Valid values are in the interval [0.0, 1.0]. Small values bias vector1. Large values bias vector2. Defaults to 0.5 - no bias.
Raises:

ValueError – If weight is less than 0.0 or greater than 1.0.
Returns:

OpenMaya.MVector – The weighted average of vector1 and vector2.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.axisAngleBetween(vector1, vector2)¶

Return the rotation that will take one vector to another in (axis, angle) form.

Parameters:
  • vector1 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
  • vector2 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
Returns:(OpenMaya.MVector, float) – A two-element tuple.
  1. The axis of rotation.
  2. The angle of rotation in radians.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.centerPoint(points)¶

Return the centroid of a set of points.

Parameters:points (iterable [iterable [numeric]]) – Array of positions in 3-dimensional projective space each represented by homogeneous coordinates [x,y,z,w].
Raises:ValueError – If points is empty.
Returns:OpenMaya.MPoint – The centroid for the set of points.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.closestPointOnLine(pointOnLine1, pointOnLine2, referencePoint)¶

Given two points that describe a line, find the projected point on that line which is closest to a given reference point.

Parameters:
  • pointOnLine1 (iterable [numeric]) – Position in 3-dimensional projective space represented by homogeneous coordinates [x,y,z,w]. Used to define a line in combination with pointOnLine2.
  • pointOnLine2 (iterable [numeric]) – Position in 3-dimensional projective space represented by homogeneous coordinates [x,y,z,w]. Must be different to pointOnLine1.
  • referencePoint (iterable [numeric]) – Position in 3-dimensional projective space represented by homogeneous coordinates [x,y,z,w]. Used as the reference point from which to find closest point on the line defined by pointOnLine1 and pointOnLine2.
Returns:

OpenMaya.MPoint – The point on the line defined by pointOnLine1 and pointOnLine2 which is closest to the referencePoint.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.composeMatrix(translation, rotation, scale)¶

Compose a transformation matrix from the given transforms.

Parameters:
  • translation (iterable [numeric]) – Translation in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
  • rotation (OpenMaya.MEulerRotation | OpenMaya.MQuaternion) – Rotation in 3-dimensional Euclidean space.
  • scale (iterable [numeric]) – Scaling in 3-dimensional Euclidean space for which elements correspond to the Cartesian axes [x,y,z].
Returns:

OpenMaya.MMatrix – Transformation matrix composed of [scale] x [rotation] x [translation].
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.crossProduct(vector1, vector2)¶

Return the cross product of two vectors.

Note

This operation is non-commutative. This operation is anticommutative

Parameters:
  • vector1 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
  • vector2 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
Returns:

OpenMaya.MVector – The cross product of vector1 with vector2.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.decomposeMatrix(matrix, rotationOrder=0, rotationAsQuarternion=False)¶

Decompose a transformation matrix into its constituent transforms.

Note

Transforms will be extracted in OpenMaya.MSpace.kTransform space, therefore matrix should represent a standard encoding of [scale] x [rotation] x [translation].

Parameters:
  • matrix (OpenMaya.MMatrix | OpenMaya.MFloatMatrix) – Transformation matrix.
  • rotationOrder (int) – Type constant from OpenMaya.MEulerRotation. Used to extract the rotation from matrix if rotationAsQuarternion is False. Defaults to OpenMaya.MEulerRotation.kXYZ.
  • rotationAsQuarternion (bool) – Whether to extract rotation transforms as a quaternion instead of an euler rotation. Defaults to False.
Returns:(OpenMaya.MVector, OpenMaya.MEulerRotation | OpenMaya.MQuaternion, OpenMaya.MVector) – A three-element tuple.
  1. Translation extracted from matrix.
  2. Rotation extracted from matrix in quaternion form if rotationAsQuarternion is True, otherwise in euler form.
  3. Scale extracted from matrix.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.distanceBetween(point1, point2)¶

Return the distance between two points.

Parameters:
  • point1 (iterable [numeric]) – Position in 3-dimensional projective space represented by homogeneous coordinates [x,y,z,w].
  • point2 (iterable [numeric]) – Position in 3-dimensional projective space represented by homogeneous coordinates [x,y,z,w].
Returns:

float – The distance between point1 and point2.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.dotProduct(vector1, vector2)¶

Return the dot product of two vectors, also known as the inner product or scalar product.

Note

This operation is commutative.

Parameters:
  • vector1 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
  • vector2 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
Returns:

float – The dot product of vector1 with vector2.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.eulerBetween(vector1, vector2, rotationOrder=0)¶

Return the rotation that will take one vector to another in euler form.

Parameters:
  • vector1 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
  • vector2 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
  • rotationOrder (int) – Type constant from OpenMaya.MEulerRotation used to set the rotation order.
Returns:

OpenMaya.MEulerRotation – The euler rotation that takes vector1 to vector2 with rotation order set to rotationOrder.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.extractEulerRotation(matrix, rotationOrder=0)¶

Extract the rotation transforms from a transformation matrix in euler form.

This will include any encoded rotation, jointOrient, rotationOrientation.

Note

See note-4 regarding assumptions pertinent to the extraction.

Parameters:
  • matrix (OpenMaya.MMatrix | OpenMaya.MFloatMatrix) – Transformation matrix.
  • rotationOrder (int) – Type constant from OpenMaya.MEulerRotation used to extract the rotation from matrix. This should be the same order that was used to encode the rotations.
Returns:

OpenMaya.MEulerRotation – Euler rotation extracted from matrix.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.extractQuaternionRotation(matrix)¶

Extract the rotation transforms from a transformation matrix in quaternion form.

This will include any encoded rotation, jointOrient, rotationOrientation.

Note

See note-4 regarding assumptions pertinent to the extraction.

Parameters:matrix (OpenMaya.MMatrix | OpenMaya.MFloatMatrix) – Transformation matrix.
Returns:OpenMaya.MQuaternion – Quaternion rotation extracted from matrix.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.extractRotationMatrix(matrix)¶

Extract a matrix representing just the rotation transforms of a transformation matrix.

This will include any encoded rotation, jointOrient, rotationOrientation.

Note

See note-4 regarding assumptions pertinent to the extraction.

Parameters:matrix (OpenMaya.MMatrix | OpenMaya.MFloatMatrix) – Transformation matrix.
Returns:OpenMaya.MMatrix – Rotation matrix extracted from matrix.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.extractScale(matrix)¶

Extract the scale transforms from a transformation matrix.

Note

See note-4 regarding assumptions pertinent to the extraction.

Parameters:matrix (OpenMaya.MMatrix | OpenMaya.MFloatMatrix) – Transformation matrix.
Returns:OpenMaya.MVector – Scale extracted from matrix, for which elements correspond to the 3-dimensional Cartesian axes [x,y,z].
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.extractScaleMatrix(matrix)¶

Extract a matrix representing just the scale transforms of a transformation matrix.

Note

See note-4 regarding assumptions pertinent to the extraction.

Parameters:matrix (OpenMaya.MMatrix | OpenMaya.MFloatMatrix) – Transformation matrix.
Returns:OpenMaya.MMatrix – Scale matrix extracted from matrix.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.extractTranslation(matrix, space=1)¶

Extract the translation transforms from a transformation matrix.

Parameters:
  • matrix (OpenMaya.MMatrix | OpenMaya.MFloatMatrix) – Transformation matrix.
  • space (int) –

    Type constant from OpenMaya.MSpace representing the space in which to extract the translation. Valid values are:

    • OpenMaya.MSpace.kTransform, OpenMaya.MSpace.kPostTransform: Depicts a space in which translation is unaffected by other transforms. Useful when matrix represents a standard encoding of [scale] x [rotation] x [translation].
    • OpenMaya.MSpace.kPreTransform: Depicts a space in which translation is affected by other transforms. Useful when matrix represents a non-standard encoding of [translation] x [scale] x [rotation].
Raises:

ValueError – If space is not one of the accepted type constants.
Returns:

OpenMaya.MVector – Translation extracted from matrix.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.extractTranslationMatrix(matrix, space=1)¶

Extract a matrix representing just the translation transforms of a transformation matrix.

Parameters:
  • matrix (OpenMaya.MMatrix | OpenMaya.MFloatMatrix) – Transformation matrix.
  • space (int) –

    Type constant from OpenMaya.MSpace representing the space in which to extract the translation. Valid values are:

    • OpenMaya.MSpace.kTransform, OpenMaya.MSpace.kPostTransform: Depicts a space in which translation is unaffected by other transforms. Useful when matrix represents a standard encoding of [scale] x [rotation] x [translation].
    • OpenMaya.MSpace.kPreTransform: Depicts a space in which translation is affected by other transforms. Useful when matrix represents a non-standard encoding of [translation] x [scale] x [rotation].
Raises:

ValueError – If space is not one of the accepted type constants.
Returns:

OpenMaya.MMatrix – Translation matrix extracted from matrix.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.isInfinitePoint(point)¶

Check if a point resides at infinity.

Parameters:point (iterable [numeric]) – Position in 3-dimensional projective space represented by homogeneous coordinates [x,y,z,w].
Returns:bool – True if any of the point coordinates evaluate to float('inf') or the coordinate w=0, otherwise False.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.isInfiniteVector(vector)¶

Check if a vector has infinite magnitude.

Parameters:vector (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
Returns:bool – True if any of the vector coordinates evaluate to float('inf'), otherwise False.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.isInfiniteVectorOrPoint(coordinates)¶

Check if a vector has infinite magnitude or a point is at infinity.

Composition of isInfiniteVector() and isInfinitePoint(), used for generic input types.

Parameters:coordinates (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z] or a position in 3-dimensional projective space represented by homogeneous coordinates [x,y,z,w].
Returns:bool – True if any of the coordinates evaluate to float('inf') or the coordinate w=0 if coordinates are homogeneous, otherwise False.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.isValid(value)¶

Check if a value is valid.

Parameters:value (numeric) – Numeric value.
Returns:bool – False if value evaluates to float('nan'), otherwise True.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.isValidPoint(point)¶

Check if a point is numerically valid.

Parameters:point (iterable [numeric]) – Position in 3-dimensional projective space represented by homogeneous coordinates [x,y,z,w].
Returns:bool – False if any of the point coordinates evaluate to float('nan') or point is equal to [0,0,0,0], otherwise True.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.isValidVector(vector)¶

Check if a vector is numerically valid.

Parameters:vector (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
Returns:bool – False if any of the vector coordinates evaluate to float('nan'), otherwise True.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.isValidVectorOrPoint(coordinates)¶

Check if a vector or point is numerically valid.

Composition of isValidVector() and isValidPoint(), used for generic input types.

Parameters:coordinates (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z] or a position in 3-dimensional projective space represented by homogeneous coordinates [x,y,z,w].
Returns:bool – False if any of the coordinates evaluate to float('nan') or the set of coordinates is equal to [0,0,0,0], otherwise True.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.mirrorMatrix(matrix, axis=0, rotation=True, translation=True)¶

Return a transformation matrix composed of transforms which have been mirrored through a plane.

Parameters:
  • matrix (OpenMaya.MMatrix | OpenMaya.MFloatMatrix) – Transformation matrix.
  • axis (int, optional) –

    Type constant from OpenMaya.MVector representing the plane to mirror transforms of matrix through. Valid values are:

    • OpenMaya.MVector.kXaxis: Mirror in the YZ plane.
    • OpenMaya.MVector.kYaxis: Mirror in the XZ plane.
    • OpenMaya.MVector.kZaxis: Mirror in the XY plane.

    Defaults to OpenMaya.MVector.kXaxis.

  • rotation (bool, optional) – Whether to mirror the rotation transforms of matrix. Defaults to True.
  • translation (bool, optional) – Whether to mirror the translation transforms of matrix. Defaults to True.
Returns:

OpenMaya.MMatrix – Transformation matrix corresponding to matrix, mirrored according to the translation and rotation arguments.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.mirrorPoint(point, axis=0)¶

Return a point mirrored through a plane represented by an axis.

Parameters:
  • point (iterable [numeric]) – Position in 3-dimensional projective space represented by homogeneous coordinates [x,y,z,w].
  • axis (int, optional) –

    Type constant from OpenMaya.MVector representing the plane to mirror point through. Valid values are:

    • OpenMaya.MVector.kXaxis: Mirror in the YZ plane.
    • OpenMaya.MVector.kYaxis: Mirror in the XZ plane.
    • OpenMaya.MVector.kZaxis: Mirror in the XY plane.

    Defaults to OpenMaya.MVector.kXaxis.
Returns:

OpenMaya.MPoint – Mirrored point.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.quaternionBetween(vector1, vector2)¶

Return the rotation that will take one vector to another in quaternion form.

Parameters:
  • vector1 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
  • vector2 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z].
Returns:

OpenMaya.MQuaternion – The quaternion rotation that takes vector1 to vector2.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.splitMatrix(matrix)¶

Extract matrices representing the individual transforms of a transformation matrix.

Note

Transforms will be extracted in OpenMaya.MSpace.kTransform space, therefore matrix should represent a standard encoding of [scale] x [rotation] x [translation].

Parameters:matrix (OpenMaya.MMatrix | OpenMaya.MFloatMatrix) – Transformation matrix.
Returns:(OpenMaya.MMatrix, OpenMaya.MMatrix, OpenMaya.MMatrix) – A three-element tuple.
  1. Translation matrix extracted from matrix.
  2. Rotation matrix extracted from matrix.
  3. Scale matrix extracted from matrix.
msTools.core.maya.math_utils.vectorProjection(vector1, vector2)¶

Given two vectors, find the projection of the first on the second.

Parameters:
  • vector1 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z]. Used as the vector to project onto vector2.
  • vector2 (iterable [numeric]) – Vector in 3-dimensional Euclidean space represented by Cartesian coordinates [x,y,z]. Used as the target vector. Must be a non-zero vector.
Raises:

ValueError – If vector2 is within the default Maya tolerance of the zero vector [0,0,0].
Returns:

OpenMaya.MVector – The vector projection of vector1 on vector2.
